ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about essay writing and internet communicaiton. However, the skills gained were minimal, which I predict would be the case for those who have had sufficient essay writing experience in the past.
I learned how to back up my arguments and that being more explicit in my writing allowed for more clarity.
How to write with a deadline in mind, write to an audience, and basic argumentative skills.

Ability to construct my arguments clearly and more deliberately
Understood internet language (CMC) from a linguistics perspective.
I gained insight into the revolutionary nature of interest language, the semantics of memes, the linguistic functionality of emojis, and many other topics surrounding internet linguistics.
I developed the skills of essay writing and ensuring that I was able to answer the questions of what my problem, tension, claim, and motive are within my essay.

I learned quite a bit about many different facets of internet language and how it has changed, developed, or been thought about throughout the internet's history. I also developed better writing skills, particularly in the realm of academic writing as well as research for writing.
learned about multi-modality of memes. some basic linguistic principles.

I learned college-level writing through the process of writing and revising the four assigned papers. I also learned about some of the fundamental concepts in linguistics and applied them to internet communication.
Having taken this course, I was able to receive constructive criticism from both my classmates and the instructor which helped me to improve my writing skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Weaknesses: The essay prompts were vague and hard to understand. The readings were sometimes dry and very dense, and many didn't add to our papers. The feedback was timely, but sometimes too pedantic. The course grading was too harsh for an intro writing class, and not very standardized across English 114 classes.

Strengths: The seminar-style of the class offered chances for lively discussion and engagement.
It would have been nice to focus more on writing techniques during class, which would be more helpful in improving my writing.
This course was well-structured.
Weakness - sometimes felt too intense, everyone was silent in class and no one spoke up. Professor did not do a great job often to dissipate this tension.

The course had a wide and interesting selection of readings that I really enjoyed discussing.

Sometimes the discussions could be a little low-energy or dry.

Strengths: There are often very engaging topics and discussions in this class; since the topic is rather contemporary, it lends itself to humor which can be extremely fun, yet we still discuss the necessary linguistic topics that allow for that humor to exist. The course material was also very diverse, which was great! 
Weaknesses: Some of the readings are a bit dense, which dissuades people from reading them. Otherwise, the course is great!

I think the variety of content is definitely a strength, as well as the way that writing assignments develop over the course of the semester to become bigger or more intense. I think the course could be improved through a stronger integration of writing assignments and class content, although I do think the course already does a good job of that.

strengths: the topic is inherently interesting, especially to gen z. the conversations were relatable.

weaknesses: the class had a lot more potential. the readings weren't the most engaging and felt a bit out-dated. i didn't feel like i was critically thinking about internet language. essay prompts were weird and difficult to write about.

Strengths: Obviously, the topic is interesting to many in various different wayseach student engages with memes, fandom, and the internet in vastly different ways, giving diverse opinions. Feedback from Holt was helpful and consistent. Most of the journal articles we read, especially in the second half of the semester, were extremely interesting and yielded some amazing discussions. Holt was very agreeable, you could tell that she was very passionate about linguistics and that she was truly trying to help you. We got a lot of freedom in our writing assignments, which was nice. 
Weaknesses: Class discussions were either extremely interesting or mind-numbingly boring, and this was due to the readings we would be assigned. We spent the majority of the first half of the semester doing readings on linguisticsthese readings were unnecessarily convoluted to the point where they were nearly impossible to comprehend without an underlying knowledge of linguistics, which many in this introductory English class did not have. As such, most of the class was spent trying to figure out what the reading was actually trying to get across instead of engaging with those ideas. Picking different readings on the same subject, finding abridged versions, or simply cutting these readings altogether would have greatly improved the class. Additionally, Holt, while a gem, can be boring at times during class. She would often go on linguistic tangents that were barely related to our days discussionthese tangents no doubt would come out of a passion for linguistics, but she would attempt to explain things that were relatively advanced in the world of linguistics without giving us any basic knowledge. While it was apparent that Holt had a lesson plan for every class, when she would go on these tangents, 1. we would run out of class time and 2. we wouldn't be able to understand what she was trying to teach us because she had not planned to teach it and was going off of her head on the blackboard.

Strengths: English 114 is a well-structured class with a manageable workload and engaging seminar style. Professor Holt was always willing to answer questions and provide feedback, and her commitment to the class helped us all to become better writers.
Weaknesses: The writing assignments were vague and difficult to interpret.
This class was very well-oriented around student-led discussion. Much of what we read the night before would be seamlessly integrated into the conversation.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. I don't think this course was particularly helpful in terms of learning new skills.
Yes. Writing is a valuable skill to have and 114 classes allow you to do so with relatively low stress levels.
Yes, if they are really interested in understanding how internet language developed and is continuously changing. If they want to study NetSpeak from an academic perspective.
I would recommend this course! The content was fascinating and well-presented.
Yes! It was a great introductory course with regard to learning how to write for Yale in the future.
Sure! I think it's a good first writing course for people at Yale. It develops writing skills in a helpful, gradual way while integrating interesting class content.
not really; audrey is a great person but the course just didn't do it for me. the topic is interesting but the class ended up being quite boring.

I would recommend this course to a student with a basic knowledge of linguistics AND who enjoys memes. I feel that I would have enjoyed the class much more if I was well-versed in the internet and in linguistics, not just one or the other. As a person who is chronically online, I really only enjoyed the parts of the class that focused heavily on social media and was bored and frustrated during the portions of the class that focused on linguistics.

This course focused heavily on linguistics, and less so on internet communication. Because I am not so interested in linguistics, I did not enjoy the readings and class discussions. However, a person who is passionate about linguistics would enjoy this course. Professor Holt was an amazing instructor and helped me to become a better writer.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student - especially if they have an interest in linguistics, the internet, and how one can shape the other.
